Woody Herman Band To Supply
Sports Dance 'Light Fantastic'
Woody Herman, "The 01'
Woodchopper," and his band will
be featured at the Senior Class's
Sports Dance, which will be held
Monday, June 1, at Gwyn Oak
Park's Dixie Ballroom. The dance
will be from 9-1 with informal
dress.
Herman's latest band, which
has been voted tops in the country by readers of "Metronome"
magazine, features seventeen instrumentalists, many of them
record stars in their own right,
and has been hailed by "Time"
magazine as "the band that
brought back dancing."
The Herman band is noted for
its great versatility, having

Students Hit U. Of M.
Leave 'H's' On Field
A group of Hopkins students
hit the University of Maryland
campus at College Park Sunday
night and left two big H's on
the field of Byrd Stadium.
According to a News-Letter
contact at College Park, the
larger H measures ten yards by
f°ur Yards and is done in royal
blue paint. The smaller one,
brushed on the grass in heavy
Motor oil, is three by two and a
half Yards.
Dean Unaware
Or. Borreson, Maryland University Dean of Students, said
that he knew nothing of the
Painting when contacted by rePorters Tuesday. Thus far the
identities of the raiders are not
known.
The lacross coach at College
park said the two H's would not
be removed before tomorrow's
game.
What may have been intended
as a retaliation occurred at
Homewood Monday night when
a carload of Maryland students

burned a small M on the grass
next to the road near Shriver
Hall. The incident brought out a
few "protection" parties who
roamed the campus in search of
the invaders.
Remsen Raided
On Wednesday morning a
large M in rod paint greeted
students from the blackboard of
Remsen 1 lecture hall. However,
it is doubtful that Terp students
are responsible.
There has been very little
other disturbance.
Students are expected to turn
out in full force for tonight's
Booster Club-sponsored pep rally
at the dormitories. Coaches,
players and cheers will be featured.
Tomorrow at 12:15 p.m. a car
caravan will leave from the Bowl
for College Park. The Booster
Club has asked that students desiring to join the caravan be
at the Bowl promptly. There will
be a police escort.

The clash of giants is at hand
as the highest scoring ten in the
history of Johns Hopkins lacrosse
faces undefeated Maryland, 1716 conquerors of National collegiate champion Army, in a door-die contest at College Park at
2:30 tomorrow afternoon.
The Terps have compiled an
impressive record as they averaged 17 goals per game in defeating ten collegiate opponents.
Only a 13-8 defeat to undefeated
Mount Washington Club in their
opening game mars Maryland's
record.
This is the game both teams
have been pointing to all year.
The battle will • be one of AllAmericans and All-candidates as
two of the strongest clubs in the
history of the 39-year old rivalry
meet to decide the 1959 national
title.
Hopkins' hopes to retain the
coveted Wingate trophy rests
mainly on the heels of their
powerful starting attack unit.
Everyone at Homewood knows of
the efficiency and machine-like
scoring punch of the Hopkins
All-Americans Billy Morrill and
Mickey Webster.
Morrill is the top scorer in the
state and is the most likely prospect for the national tally title
with 40 goals in eight contests
(an average of five per game).
Only Maryland's Roger Goss,
with 36 in ten battles, is challenging Morrill's title hopes.
Webster has no claimants to
his assists crown. With 42 feeds
on the season, Mickey is undisputed king of the hill.
In addition to his goal-tallying
ability,
Morrill's
dodge-andweaves have resulted in 21 assists, most of which have contributed to Webster's 14 goals.
Bruce Duffany, with 19 goals
and 7 assists, rounds out a powerful attack that has contributed
one-half of the Jays' 154 goals
(19 per game) this season.

Lukens To See Russia Hoodlums Burglarize Rooms,
On YMCA Exchange Slash Clothes In New Dorms
Mike Lukens is one of 22 collegiate YMCA members in the
United States chosen as exchange student to the Soviet
Union this summer.

The YMCA program to promote "cultural, scholarly, and
individual contacts between the
Soviet Union and the West" was
initiated last summer. Participants in the program are chosen
on the basis of YMCA experience
academic
well-rounded
and
achievement.
Lukens has been a member of
the National Student Committee
of the YMCA and has been
active on the local, regional and
national level of the organization for the last three years. He
is president of the Hopkins
chapter of the Y. He was also
vice-president of the Dormitory
Students Representatives Council this year and a member of
ODK, honorary leadership society, and Delta Phi Alpha, honorary German fraternity.
Cost of Lukens' trip to Russia
this summer will be $1400. His
expenses will be partially defrayed by grants from area
YMCAs and grants voted him
by the Student Council and the
Cotillion Board this week, as well
as contributions from local civil
groups and private persons.

student exchange program is to

The thefts occurred between
2:00 and 4:00 p.m. when most of
the dorm residents were.up at
the big lacrosse game. When the
students returned and discovered
that they had been robbed, they
immediately called the police.
Further investigation showed
that the thieves had hit every
house in the new dorms and that
they had entered only unlocked
rooms. The police, upon arrival,
took the complaints of the irate
victims.

Slashed Clothing
It was discovered, however,
that the group had slashed
clothing with razor blades, and
had passed up many articles of
higher value in plain sight. This
indicated that the robbery might

MIKE LUKENS

have had something more than
personal gain as its chief motive.
It has been rumored that it
might have been an act of retaliation on the part of the
hoodlums captured by a group
of students from Wilson House
two weeks ago.
Police reports at Northern District Police Station itemized
much of the stolen property.
Ten dorm residents and other
students filed complaints with
the investigating officers. One
student lost as much as $62.00
worth of clothing. Another lost
an airplane bag containing
$51.00 worth of valuables. Three
boys lost a total of $107 in rings
and watches.
Brunt Of Losses
The brunt of the losses were
sustained by four boys who were
robbed of $203 in merchandise.
As mentioned before, the sum
total of losses reported to the
police was $330. According to
em District Police Station, the

Lt. Joseph Burke at the North..
case is still under investigation.
Miss Wasserberg, dormitory
manager, said that she had received only one or two reports
of thefts as of Tuesday. She
said that when she receives some
more complaints she will call in
the detective agency to investigate. Miss Wasserberg claimed
that she was very sorry about
what had happened but stated
"the boys got what they deserved because they did not lock
their rooms." She continued
saying that students have been
warned repeatedly to lock their
rooms to avoid theft.

and Bill Nape as Secretary

By STEPHEN B. HORTON
Features Editor

Business Manager
Michael W. Arthur

Alert, alarm of fire, alert
alarm of fire!
At the watch desk of Engine
Company 9, Baltimore City Fire
Department, located on the corner of Madison and McDonogh
streets, the "squawk box" blares.
Seconds later, the register, a device which punches triangular
holes into a paper tape, begins to
grind fitfully. As the tape feeds
out, a bell rings each time a hole
is punched. Two - Seven - Two Two. Firefighter Joe Walters,
taking the nine to midnight
watch, "hits the gong." He
knows from years of experience
that Box 2722, at Chase and McDonogh, "is ours."

Eenie, Meanie ...
Perhaps the only virtue in the DSRC's recent action
of giving house presidents the right to draw up lists of
dormitory undesirables is a negative one—it takes such
action out of the hands of the administration, and places
it in those of the students themselves.
According to social custom this should provide the
fairest results, by allowing students to judge themselves.
Yet the action is a dangerous one, priniarily for the
fact that it is not an organized system and no criteria
have been determined by which a student is classed as an
"offender." The house presidents themselves have not
been chosen for the job and may misuse it. That they
"don't want to squeal on their buddies" is understandable,
!Alt that they may report students out of pure animosity
or ill will is a precarious possibility.
The method of selecting those who will be the first to
be replaced is under any guise a necessary evil unless
new dormitory facilities can be provided—a distinct improbability. The system as it is set up now is the best
of a bad lot of possibilities, and has the potentiality of
being harmful as well as it does of being beneficial.
Potentially the system can alert what this year has
been a lackadaisical group of house presidents to become
a board cognizant of the responsibility of office. It can
likewise incite widespread animosity and hard feelings
among students and the DSRC.
The lack of a standardized procedure or regulation
for drawing up these lists, as well as the evidence that
some house presidents have flatly refused to comply with
the DSRC's request for these lists, points up the fact that
the system is weak. Unless a complete and agreed-upon
system is set up, the DSRC is knifing itself as well as the
students in the back.
In the light of the situation and its possible ramifications, we stand back to watch the proceedings.

Social Bungling
The Starlighter, usually one of the University's more
successful social affairs, this year turned out to be a fiasco.
The blame for the poorly managed dance must be shared
by both the H Club and the chairman of the dance, Charles
Beinkampen.

The DSRC will sponsor a
Shipwreck Dance tonight from
9 to 1 on the Snack Bar terrace. Admission will be $1.50
and the dance is open to all.
Dress will be informal, with a
prize awarded to the person

the distribution of favors at

on sale all week and a large
crowd is expected.

Clambake

this Sunday, May 17, at 2 p.m.
at Beaver Dam, Cockeysville.
It will be open to all classes.
Beer, hot dogs, clams, swimming, soft ball, badminton,

Van Dykes will be available.

and '62 are sponsoring the

available from their class officers.

Keeping Its Word,
Gouncher Arrests,
Fines 2 Thieves
Two Hopkins undergraduates
were convicted on charges of
petty larceny and fined $25 each
plus costs Tuesday after a raid
on the Goucher campus which
almost netted them two lawn
chairs.
The offense occurred early
Sunday morning. Goucher campus policeman Charles Wilson,
on the alert for a panty raid,
spotted
boys sneaking
two
through the bushes.
Upon closing in he found them
dragging lawn chairs and stowing them in a parked car. The
two petty thiefs, both Hopkins
freshmen, spent the night in a
Towson jail.
At Tuesday's hearing, Towson
Magistrate William S. Baldwn
convicted the two on counts of
petty larceny after dismissing
charges of trespassing that had
been levied by Goucher authorities. The students pleaded innocent of the latter charge,
maintaining that they had come
on campus to return their dates
about midnight.
Baldwin said he regarded
pranks such as stealing lawn
chairs in a different light than
simply being on campus talking
to girls.
.The two students admitted the
larceny and also confessed that
they had been riding bicycles
around the Goucher campus.
Last week the same Magistrate
suspended fines on three Hopkins students and dismissed
charges on a fourth after they
allegedly staged a small panty
raid on Goucher a week previously.

DSRC representatives will decide this week which students in
their entries should be expelled
from the dorms next year if the

space
expected
realized.
As a result of Monday's DSRC
meeting, each outgoing entry
representative is being asked to
submit to the council a list of
those students he considers undeserving of scarce dormitory
Space because of their conduct
during the year.
The plan unveiled in the council Monday night calls for house
Presidents to submit two lists.
One will include students considered habitual, uncorrectible
offenders who should be the first
to leave the dorms. The second
is to contain borderline cases
Who could stay in the dorms
snace permitting.
Room Shortage?
Opinion among council members as to whether or not the
dorms would be overcrowded
next year was divided this week.
Miss Wasserberg asserted that
no estimate of a space shortage
can be made until final dormitory assignments are made during the next week, and many

Eenie, Meanie ...
Perhaps the only virtue in the DSRC's recent action
of giving house presidents the right to draw up lists of
dormitory undesirables is a negative one—it takes such
action out of the hands of the administration, and places
it in those of the students themselves.
According to social custom this should provide the
fairest results, by allowing students to judge themselves.
Yet the action is a dangerous one, priniarily for the
fact that it is not an organized system and no criteria
have been determined by which a student is classed as an
"offender." The house presidents themselves have not
been chosen for the job and may misuse it. That they
"don't want to squeal on their buddies" is understandable,
!Alt that they may report students out of pure animosity
or ill will is a precarious possibility.
The method of selecting those who will be the first to
be replaced is under any guise a necessary evil unless
new dormitory facilities can be provided—a distinct improbability. The system as it is set up now is the best
of a bad lot of possibilities, and has the potentiality of
being harmful as well as it does of being beneficial.
Potentially the system can alert what this year has
been a lackadaisical group of house presidents to become
a board cognizant of the responsibility of office. It can
likewise incite widespread animosity and hard feelings
among students and the DSRC.
The lack of a standardized procedure or regulation
for drawing up these lists, as well as the evidence that
some house presidents have flatly refused to comply with
the DSRC's request for these lists, points up the fact that
the system is weak. Unless a complete and agreed-upon
system is set up, the DSRC is knifing itself as well as the
students in the back.
In the light of the situation and its possible ramifications, we stand back to watch the proceedings.

by both the H Club and the chairman of the dance, Charles
Beinkampen.

DSRC Dance
The DSRC will sponsor a
Shipwreck Dance tonight from
9 to 1 on the Snack Bar terrace. Admission will be $1.50
and the dance is open to all.
Dress will be informal, with a
prize awarded to the person
dressed in the best "shipwreck" costume.
Music by Russ DOugan and
the distribution of favors at
the door will highlight the
festivities In case of rain the
dance will be held inside the
Snack Bar. Tickets have been
on sale all week and a large
crowd is expected.

Clambake
The clambake will be held
this Sunday, May 17, at 2 p.m.
at Beaver Dam, Cockeysville.
It will be open to all classes.
Beer, hot dogs, clams, swimming, soft ball, badminton,
dancing, and music by the
Van Dykes will be available.
The price is $3.50 per couple,
$2.00 stag. The classes of '61
and '62 are sponsoring the
event, and map directions are
available from their class officers.

Keeping Its Word,
Gouncher Arrests,
Fines 2 Thieves
Two Hopkins undergraduates
were convicted on charges of
petty larceny and fined $25 each
plus costs Tuesday after a raid
on the Goucher campus which
almost netted them two lawn
chairs.
The offense occurred early
Sunday morning. Goucher campus policeman Charles Wilson,
on the alert for a panty raid,
spotted
boys sneaking
two
through the bushes.
Upon closing in he found them
dragging lawn chairs and stowing them in a parked car. The
two petty thiefs, both Hopkins
freshmen, spent the night in a
Towson jail.
At Tuesday's hearing, Towson
Magistrate William S. Baldwn
convicted the two on counts of
petty larceny after dismissing
charges of trespassing that had
been levied by Goucher authorities. The students pleaded innocent of the latter charge,
maintaining that they had come
on campus to return their dates
about midnight.
Baldwin said he regarded
pranks such as stealing lawn
chairs in a different light than
simply being on campus talking
to girls.
.The two students admitted the
larceny and also confessed that
they had been riding bicycles
around the Goucher campus.
Last week the same Magistrate
suspended fines on three Hopkins students and dismissed
charges on a fourth after they
allegedly staged a small panty
raid on Goucher a week previously.

ended abruptly last week as the
Jays bowed to Navy by a 12-3
score.

a season record of 2-5. They beat
Kenwood and Glen Burnie high
schools, while losing to Frederick
( twice), Baltimore Junior Co!
lege, and Calvert Hall.

Meyers, shortstop and catcher,
and Bobby Raub, at third base.
